de.mslab.ciphers

Class Khazad

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.mslab.ciphers.Khazad
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    BlockCipher, RoundBasedBlockCipher

    public class Khazad
extends java.lang.Object
    Implements the KHAZAD block cipher, designed 1998 by Rijmen and Barreto.

      If the RoundBasedBlockCipher.canInvertKeySchedule() method returns true, the cipher can invert the key schedule and reconstruct the secret key and all other round keys from one given round key.

    • Method Detail

      • canInvertKeySchedule

        public boolean canInvertKeySchedule()
        Description copied from interface: RoundBasedBlockCipher
        Some ciphers, for instance the AES, can invert its key schedule. Returns true, if this is the case for this cipher instance. Returns false otherwise.

      • computeExpandedKey

        public ByteArray computeExpandedKey(ByteArray keyPart,
                           int round)
        Description copied from interface: RoundBasedBlockCipher
        If the RoundBasedBlockCipher.canInvertKeySchedule() method returns true, the cipher can invert the key schedule and reconstruct the secret key and all other round keys from one given round key. This method computes the expanded secret key from (a) given round key(s), and the mentioned round.
        Specified by:
        computeExpandedKey in interface RoundBasedBlockCipher
        Parameters:
        keyPart - A portion of the expanded key.
        round - The round, in which the portion of the expanded key starts. Example: if the given round is 2, and the length of the given keyPart equals the stateSize of the cipher, then the keyPart is expected to hold the round key for round 2. The implementation of this method should then reconstruct all missing round keys for rounds 1, 3, 4, ..., numRounds, and, if needed, whitening keys for rounds 0, numRounds + 1. Another Example: if the given round is numRounds, and the keyPart extends the stateSize of the cipher. Then the given keyPart is expected to hold the round key for the last round, and more material, which is interpreted as key for round numRounds + 1, numRounds + 2, ... until its end. Such additional material is (!) used to create round keys numRounds - 1, numRounds - 2, ... .
        See Also:
        RoundBasedBlockCipher.canInvertKeySchedule()

      • decryptRounds

        public ByteArray decryptRounds(ByteArray block,
                      int fromRound,
                      int toRound)
        Description copied from interface: RoundBasedBlockCipher
        Performs a decryption over some rounds from toRound to including fromRound of the given block with the current key.

      • injectsKeyAtRoundEnd

        public boolean injectsKeyAtRoundEnd(int round)
        Description copied from interface: RoundBasedBlockCipher
        Returns true, if the cipher injects the round keys always as the last operation in a round. False otherwise.
        Specified by:
        injectsKeyAtRoundEnd in interface RoundBasedBlockCipher
        Parameters:
        round - The given round.

      • setKey

        public void setKey(ByteArray key)
        Description copied from interface: BlockCipher
        Sets the secret key used for encryption and decryption. Internally, the cipher will be expected to check if the size of the given key is correct, and run the key schedule.

      • setExpandedKey

        public void setExpandedKey(ByteArray expandedKey)
        Description copied from interface: BlockCipher
        Sets the expanded key with all round keys. Internally, the cipher will be expected to check if the size of the given key is correct. This method will explicitly not run the key schedule.

      • addRoundKey

        public ByteArray addRoundKey(int round,
                    ByteArray state)
        Description copied from interface: RoundBasedBlockCipher
        Performs a round-key injection on the state, that means, the state is XORed with the round key for the passed round. The state is updated and returned.
        Specified by:
        addRoundKey in interface RoundBasedBlockCipher

      • getNumActiveComponentsInEncryption

        public int getNumActiveComponentsInEncryption(int numRounds)
        Returns the number of active bits/bytes/nibbles in non-linear operations in a given number of rounds.
        Specified by:
        getNumActiveComponentsInEncryption in interface RoundBasedBlockCipher
        Returns:
        Returns default values for byte-wise and nibble-wise operating ciphers. numRounds * 2 * stateSize for byte-wise, numRounds * stateSize for nibble-wise ciphers.
